title: Jass Card design
description:
# Swiss Jass AI card deck generator: platforms, prompts, and production pipeline

**FLUX Kontext on ComfyUI is the strongest production path for generating 36 consistent Swiss Jass cards**, with Weavy.ai (now Figma Weave) as a compelling prototyping alternative and OpenArt.ai as the fastest manual testing ground. The three complete prompt template sets below — Fun Cartoon, Escher Geometric, and Dark Fantasy — each use a modular architecture that separates style (constant) from content (variable), enabling batch generation across all 36 cards while preserving visual cohesion. The key insight from community card projects: **generate art illustrations separately, then composite onto card templates** — never try to generate a complete card in one shot.

---

## Platform comparison: Weavy.ai, ComfyUI, and OpenArt.ai

### Weavy.ai (now Figma Weave)

Weavy.ai is a **browser-based, node-based AI creative workflow platform** founded in Tel Aviv in 2024 and acquired by Figma in October 2025 for $200+ million. It chains multiple AI models (image, video, 3D, text/LLM) with professional editing tools on an infinite canvas.

For Swiss Jass card generation, Weavy's standout feature is its **Iterator Nodes**: a Text Iterator combined with an Array Node can send all 36 card prompts to a generative model simultaneously, with cloud servers spinning up in parallel. It supports **FLUX Fast, Dev (with LoRA), Kontext, and Pro Ultra**, plus Ideogram V3, GPT Image 1, Stable Diffusion 3.5, Imagen 4, and dozens more. Custom LoRAs can be imported from CivitAI, Hugging Face, and Replicate. Compositing tools (layers, masking, color grading, relighting) are built into the node graph, enabling post-processing as part of the pipeline.

**Pricing** ranges from free (150 credits/month, enough for ~375 Flux Fast images) to Professional at $45/month (4,000 credits). A full 36-card batch using Flux Dev with LoRA costs approximately **144 credits** — well within the Starter plan. Commercial rights are included.

**Key limitation**: Weavy exposes fewer granular parameters than ComfyUI. You cannot fine-tune ControlNet scheduling or sampler configurations. The API for programmatic automation is "coming soon" on the Enterprise tier, meaning current workflows require browser interaction. For prototyping and visual pipeline design, Weavy is excellent. For production automation of hundreds of decks, **ComfyUI remains superior**.

### ComfyUI: the production powerhouse

ComfyUI offers the deepest control for card generation through its open-source node ecosystem. Several community workflows already exist for card generation:

- **ArtisMysterium's 6-Lane Playing Card Workflow** (Civitai, 465+ downloads): Generates card elements separately across six parallel lanes — background, title, cost symbol, main illustration, description, and borders — then composites them. Uses LayerDiffuse for transparency and SDXL checkpoints. This composite approach is **far more controllable** than single-shot generation.
- **matt3o's Trading Card Game Maker** (OpenArt): Complex compositing template using IP-Adapter for style reference and 14 preview nodes for QA.
- **NEAR Monsters NFT Card Game**: A full production pipeline using SDXL + ComfyUI, automated via Python scripts that intercepted API calls. Used a custom ImageCurator webapp for accept/reject workflows and GPT-V for card naming.

**FLUX Kontext integration** is the most promising technology for card-to-card consistency. The 12B-parameter model supports character consistency from a single reference, style transfer, and iterative editing with minimal drift. ComfyUI loads Kontext natively via `flux1-dev-kontext_fp8_scaled.safetensors`, with multi-image input through Image Stitch nodes or chained ReferenceLatent nodes. Minimum 12GB VRAM (GGUF quantized), 24GB+ recommended.

For **face preservation on court cards**, the recommended stack is **PuLID for FLUX** (`ComfyUI-PuLID-Flux`), which achieves zero "model pollution" — preserving artistic style while swapping faces. The combined **Flux Kontext + PuLID workflow** provides the best modern approach: Kontext handles style/context, PuLID handles identity. InstantID remains an option for SDXL-only workflows but is in maintenance mode.

**Batch automation** is solved through multiple approaches: the ComfyUI Inspire Pack's `LoadPromptsFromFile` node reads prompt files with positive/negative sections; `comfy-batcher` queues thousands of prompts via the REST API; and the native API endpoint (`/prompt`) accepts JSON workflow submissions monitored via WebSocket. A Python script iterating through 36 card definitions in CSV/JSON, modifying prompt text and input images per card, is the recommended production approach.

### OpenArt.ai: fastest manual testing

OpenArt aggregates **100+ models** including FLUX Kontext Pro, FLUX Dev, GPT Image 1, Imagen 4, Gemini, and SDXL variants under one interface. It has **dedicated playing card and tarot card generators** with example prompts, making it the fastest way to test prompt templates before automating.

The platform's **Image Guidance system** supports five reference types simultaneously: Style, Composition, Face, Pose, and General references. For card testing, Style Reference + Composition Reference is the most useful pairing. FLUX Dev provides the most controls (CFG slider, steps, seed, upscale options). The **Characters Beta** feature trains a consistent character from 1-4+ photos in ~10 minutes for **1,000 credits**, directly enabling court card face consistency.

**Batch generation** via CSV (up to 500 images at once) is available on Advanced plans ($14.50/month), though OpenArt has announced reworking this feature. The free tier is limited to 512×512 without image guidance — the Essential plan ($7/month) is the minimum for card art testing with references.

---

## The modular prompt template architecture

All three style sets below use a **four-layer modular system** that cleanly separates concerns:

```
FINAL_PROMPT = {STYLE_LAYER} + {COMPOSITION_LAYER} + {CONTENT_LAYER} + {QUALITY_LAYER}
```

**Layer 1 — Style Layer** remains constant across all 36 cards within a style. It defines the artistic medium, color philosophy, rendering technique, and mood. This is the "style bible" enforced on every generation.

**Layer 2 — Composition Layer** varies by card type (court, pip, ace) but stays consistent within each type across all four suits. It defines layout, framing, and spatial relationships.

**Layer 3 — Content Layer** is unique per card. It specifies the subject, suit-specific elements, and rank-specific details. This is the only layer that changes for every single card.

**Layer 4 — Quality Layer** remains constant. It specifies resolution, rendering quality, and critical exclusions.

For FLUX models, prompts should use **natural language paragraphs** rather than comma-separated keywords. FLUX pays more attention to words at the beginning of prompts. For SDXL, comma-separated keywords with emphasis brackets work best.

```python
# Production template system (Python pseudocode)
def generate_prompt(style: str, suit: str, rank: str) -> str:
    style_layer = STYLES[style]["global"]
    composition = COMPOSITIONS[get_card_type(rank)]
    content = CONTENT[rank].format(
        suit_symbol=SUITS[style][suit]["symbol"],
        suit_colors=SUITS[style][suit]["colors"],
        character=CHARACTERS[style][suit].get(rank, "")
    )
    quality = QUALITY_LAYERS[style]
    return f"{style_layer}, {composition}, {content}, {quality}"
```

---

## Style A — Fun/Whimsical Cartoon: complete template set

### Global style reference (constant across all 36 cards)

```
STYLE_A_GLOBAL = "Whimsical cartoon illustration in ligne claire style with bold clean 
outlines, flat vibrant color areas, smooth cel-shading, playful European comic book 
aesthetic inspired by Studio Ghibli warmth and Franco-Belgian bande dessinée precision, 
cheerful storybook illustration for a playing card, hand-drawn feel with digital 
polish, warm soft lighting"
```

### Suit-specific color palettes and motifs

| Suit | Primary Colors | Motif Keywords | Symbol Description |
|------|---------------|----------------|-------------------|
| **Schellen (Bells)** | Warm golden yellow, orange-amber, cherry red | Festive, musical, jingling, carnival | `a cheerful round golden sleigh bell with a smiling face, warm amber glow` |
| **Schilten (Shields)** | Royal blue, silver-white, sky blue | Noble, protective, heraldic, steadfast | `a round cartoon heraldic shield with a friendly crest design, polished silver-blue` |
| **Eicheln (Acorns)** | Forest green, warm brown, amber | Woodland, cozy, autumn, natural | `a plump friendly acorn with a cute cap, nestled among oak leaves, earthy brown-green` |
| **Rosen (Roses)** | Bright pink-red, soft green, coral | Romantic, blooming, garden, elegant | `a cheerful blooming cartoon rose with soft petals and curling leaves, pink-red` |

### Court card templates (König, Ober, Under)

**König (King) — all suits:**
```
{STYLE_A_GLOBAL}, full portrait of a charming cartoon king character wearing an 
oversized golden crown, {suit_colors} royal robes with {suit_symbol} embroidery, 
holding a {suit_symbol} scepter, large expressive eyes, warm dignified smile, 
exaggerated round proportions, seated on a whimsical throne decorated with 
{suit_symbol}s, ornate decorative card border with {suit_symbol} corner motifs, 
symmetric double-ended playing card layout, white background, high detail, 
4K resolution, clean linework, no text, no watermark, no numbers
```

**Ober (Officer) — all suits:**
```
{STYLE_A_GLOBAL}, full portrait of a dashing cartoon officer character in a plumed 
hat, {suit_colors} uniform jacket with golden buttons and {suit_symbol} insignia, 
confident cheerful expression, large expressive eyes, standing at attention holding 
a {suit_symbol} upward, playful military pose, ornate decorative card border with 
{suit_symbol} corner motifs, symmetric double-ended playing card layout, white 
background, high detail, 4K, clean linework, no text, no watermark
```

**Under (Jack) — suit-specific characters:**
- **Schellen Under**: `a mischievous cartoon jester with donkey-ear cap adorned with tiny golden bells, playful trickster expression, juggling bells`
- **Schilten Under**: `a young cartoon scribe with round spectacles and a quill pen, holding a small shield, studious but cheerful`
- **Eicheln Under**: `a sturdy cartoon woodsman with a green cap and acorn-topped walking stick, friendly outdoorsy expression`
- **Rosen Under**: `a charming young cartoon gardener with rosy cheeks and a flower crown, holding roses, gentle and bright`

### Pip card templates (6 through 9)

```
{STYLE_A_GLOBAL}, a decorative arrangement of {N} {suit_symbol}s in a symmetric 
pattern on a playing card surface, connected by whimsical curling vine decorations 
and tiny cartoon flourishes, {suit_colors} palette, playful spacing, each {suit_symbol} 
slightly unique in expression, ornate decorative card border matching court cards, 
flat centered composition, white background, high detail, clean linework, no text, 
no numbers, no watermark
```

### Special cards

**Banner (10):** `{STYLE_A_GLOBAL}, a festive cartoon banner flag decorated with a large {suit_symbol} centerpiece, surrounded by ten smaller {suit_symbol}s woven into ribbon streamers, celebratory composition, {suit_colors}, ornate card border, no text`

**Ass (Ace):** `{STYLE_A_GLOBAL}, a single magnificent oversized {suit_symbol} filling the center of the card, surrounded by elaborate cartoon flourishes, tiny woodland creatures, and decorative storybook scrollwork, {suit_colors}, maximum ornamentation, showcase centerpiece card, ornate border, no text`

### Negative prompt for Style A
```
photorealistic, photography, 3D render, dark moody, horror, gritty, hatching, 
cross-hatching, blurry, low quality, extra fingers, bad anatomy, watermark, text, 
signature, realistic skin texture, film grain, noise, muddy colors, desaturated, 
gothic, scary, violent, blood
```

### Consistency enforcement for Style A

- **LoRA approach**: Train on 30-40 images of ligne claire / Franco-Belgian comic illustrations. CivitAI has existing "cartoon style" LoRAs to start from.
- **Midjourney `--sref`**: Generate one perfect König of Bells first, then use its URL as `--sref` for all 35 remaining cards.
- **FLUX Kontext**: Generate the hero card, then prompt: *"Maintain the exact same cartoon illustration style, linework weight, and color saturation, but change the subject to [X]"*
- **Fixed elements**: Every card shares the same border pattern, the same outline weight, and the same background tone.

---

## Style B — Escher-Inspired Geometric: complete template set

### Global style reference

```
STYLE_B_GLOBAL = "MC Escher inspired geometric illustration, lithographic woodcut 
engraving style, impossible geometry and tessellation patterns, mathematical 
precision with intricate linework, Art Deco influences, limited color palette with 
high contrast, negative and positive space interplay, interlocking shapes, 
symmetrical composition, optical illusion elements, clean geometric precision"
```

### Suit-specific palettes and geometric motifs

| Suit | Palette (3 colors max) | Geometric Concept | Symbol Treatment |
|------|----------------------|-------------------|-----------------|
| **Schellen (Bells)** | Gold-amber, black, cream-white | Bell silhouettes as tessellation units, sound-wave concentric circles | `geometric bell silhouette formed from interlocking triangular shapes, amber-gold on black` |
| **Schilten (Shields)** | Deep navy, silver-white, black | Shield outlines forming hexagonal tiling, heraldic geometry | `geometric shield shape as hexagonal tessellation unit, navy and silver, sharp edges` |
| **Eicheln (Acorns)** | Dark brown, forest green, cream | Acorn forms as repeating drop-shaped tessellations, oak-leaf fractals | `stylized geometric acorn as tessellation element, brown and green interlocking pattern` |
| **Rosen (Roses)** | Deep crimson, black, white | Five-petal rose symmetry mapping to pentagonal tiling, spiraling geometry | `geometric five-petal rose as pentagonal tessellation unit, crimson on black` |

### Court card templates

**König (King) — Escher style:**
```
{STYLE_B_GLOBAL}, a regal king figure composed entirely of interlocking geometric 
tessellated {suit_symbol} shapes, seated on an impossible staircase throne inspired 
by Penrose stairs, the figure formed through negative and positive space interplay, 
crown made of repeating geometric patterns, {suit_colors} limited palette, 
lithographic woodcut rendering, symmetric double-ended playing card layout, 
mathematical precision, Art Deco geometric border with {suit_symbol} tessellation 
pattern, high contrast, intricate linework, no text
```

**Ober (Officer) — Escher style:**
```
{STYLE_B_GLOBAL}, a standing officer figure emerging from an Escher-style metamorphosis 
pattern, the figure's uniform transforming into {suit_symbol} tessellations that tile 
the background, impossible perspective architecture behind the figure, {suit_colors} 
limited palette, figure holds {suit_symbol} aloft, geometric precision, 
lithographic engraving style, Art Deco border, symmetric card layout, no text
```

**Under (Jack) — Escher style:**
```
{STYLE_B_GLOBAL}, a young figure in motion within an impossible geometric space, 
Escher-style recursive architecture, the figure's clothing pattern tessellates 
with {suit_symbol} shapes, Möbius strip elements, figure-ground reversal between 
character and {suit_symbol} pattern, {suit_colors} limited palette, woodcut 
engraving style, geometric card border, symmetric layout, no text
```

### Pip card templates

```
{STYLE_B_GLOBAL}, {N} {suit_symbol}s arranged in an Escher-style tessellation 
pattern, interlocking shapes creating a seamless geometric design that fills the 
card surface, each {suit_symbol} formed by the negative space of its neighbors, 
impossible perspective depth, {suit_colors} limited palette, mathematical precision, 
Penrose tiling influence, Art Deco geometric border, high contrast, no gaps in 
pattern, woodcut engraving rendering, no text
```

### Special cards

**Banner (10):** `{STYLE_B_GLOBAL}, an Escher-style metamorphosis composition where ten {suit_symbol}s gradually transform into each other across the card surface, morphing from realistic to abstract geometric forms, banner motif integrated into impossible architecture, {suit_colors}, Art Deco border, no text`

**Ass (Ace):** `{STYLE_B_GLOBAL}, a single monumental {suit_symbol} at center constructed from fractal recursive patterns, each part containing smaller versions of itself, surrounded by impossible geometric architecture, maximum geometric complexity, {suit_colors}, Art Deco border with tessellation, showcase card, no text`

### Card back design (unique to Escher style)
```
{STYLE_B_GLOBAL}, a seamless Escher-style tessellation where bell shapes morph 
into shield shapes morph into acorn shapes morph into rose shapes in a continuous 
metamorphosis pattern, all four Swiss Jass suits interlocking perfectly with no 
gaps, gold amber navy crimson brown color accents on black background, 
mathematically perfect tiling, symmetric, no text
```

### Negative prompt for Style B
```
photorealistic, organic textures, painterly, impressionist, watercolor, soft focus, 
natural lighting, random patterns, asymmetrical chaos, cartoon, anime, bright 
cheerful colors, pastel, extra fingers, bad anatomy, noisy, grainy, text, 
watermark, cluttered, busy, scattered elements, gaps in pattern
```

### Consistency enforcement for Style B

- **ControlNet is critical**: Create geometric guide images (depth maps with the tessellation grid) and use ControlNet to maintain mathematical precision across all 36 cards.
- **Limited palette enforcement**: Define exact hex values per suit and match across all cards in post-processing.
- **Geometric vocabulary**: Define 3-4 base geometric motifs per suit and reuse them identically.
- AI struggles with true mathematical tessellations. Expect **significant post-processing** or use ControlNet with pre-designed geometric templates. Style B is the hardest of the three to execute purely through prompting.

---

## Style C — Game of Thrones / Dark Fantasy: complete template set

### Global style reference

```
STYLE_C_GLOBAL = "Dark fantasy concept art illustration, dramatic chiaroscuro 
lighting with deep shadows and warm firelight, moody medieval atmosphere, 
oil painting style with rich texture, ornate gothic architectural details, 
weathered and battle-worn aesthetic, hyper-detailed intricate ornamentation, 
cinematic composition, dark color palette with selective dramatic highlights, 
concept art by Greg Rutkowski and Craig Mullins, medieval manuscript 
illumination border elements"
```

### Suit-specific dark fantasy transformations

| Suit | Fantasy Transformation | Palette | Atmosphere |
|------|----------------------|---------|------------|
| **Schellen (Bells)** | Ancient iron bells with arcane runes, cracked and glowing from within, hung on dungeon chains | Dark gold, burnished bronze, blood-red highlights, black | Torchlight, dungeon, ominous tolling |
| **Schilten (Shields)** | Battle-scarred kite shields with heraldic crests, mounted on castle walls, dented and scratched | Steel grey, midnight blue, dark crimson, silver | Moonlight, castle armory, cold and martial |
| **Eicheln (Acorns)** | Mystical glowing acorns from an ancient world-tree, druidic power, surrounded by gnarled roots | Deep forest green, dark brown, amber inner glow, moss | Misty ancient forest, ethereal light |
| **Rosen (Roses)** | Thorned black-crimson roses, sometimes bleeding, dark romantic Gothic beauty | Deep crimson, black, dark purple, blood red | Candlelight, Gothic garden, romantic darkness |

### Court card templates

**König (King) — Dark Fantasy:**
```
{STYLE_C_GLOBAL}, a battle-hardened dark fantasy king seated on a stone throne 
in a cavernous castle hall, wearing ornate dark steel plate armor engraved with 
{suit_symbol} heraldic crests, heavy fur-trimmed cloak, iron crown set with 
dark gems, {suit_specific_atmosphere}, {suit_colors} palette, volumetric fog 
and {lighting_type}, intricate armor detailing with scratches and patina, 
medieval manuscript illumination style ornate border with Gothic tracery and 
{suit_symbol} motifs, symmetric double-ended playing card layout, 8K resolution, 
no text, no watermark
```

**Ober (Officer) — Dark Fantasy:**
```
{STYLE_C_GLOBAL}, a stern armored commander standing in {suit_environment}, 
wearing burnished chainmail and leather with {suit_symbol} sigil on breastplate, 
gauntleted hand gripping a {suit_weapon} held upward, weathered face with 
battle scars, {suit_colors} palette, dramatic rim lighting against deep shadows, 
medieval manuscript illuminated border with {suit_symbol} Gothic tracery, 
symmetric card layout, 8K, no text
```

**Under (Jack) — Dark Fantasy, suit-specific:**
- **Schellen Under**: `a gaunt sinister court jester in tattered motley, fool's cap hung with corroded iron bells, haunting grin, holding a rusted bell-topped scepter, dungeon torchlight, chains and shadows`
- **Schilten Under**: `a young squire in battered leather armor, kneeling to present a shield, earnest determination in eyes, rain-soaked castle courtyard, cold blue moonlight`
- **Eicheln Under**: `a druidic forest ranger in bark-textured leather and moss-green cloak, staff crowned with a glowing acorn, ancient misty oak forest, ethereal green light filtering through canopy`
- **Rosen Under**: `a dark romantic figure in thorned rose-vine armor, pale face, holding a single bleeding black rose, Gothic garden with iron gates, candlelight and shadow`

### Pip card templates

```
{STYLE_C_GLOBAL}, {N} {dark_fantasy_suit_symbol}s arranged in a heraldic pattern 
against a dark {suit_environment} background, each {suit_symbol} rendered with 
intricate weathered detail and {suit_atmosphere}, connected by Gothic ornamental 
ironwork and dark vine scrollwork, {suit_colors} palette, dramatic {lighting_type}, 
medieval manuscript illumination border with Gothic tracery, moody atmospheric 
composition, 8K, no text
```

### Special cards

**Banner (10):** `{STYLE_C_GLOBAL}, an epic dark fantasy battle banner emblazoned with a massive {dark_fantasy_suit_symbol}, torn and weather-beaten, mounted on a war-scarred pole, surrounded by ten smaller {suit_symbol}s forged in dark iron, {suit_environment} background, {suit_colors}, dramatic wind and {lighting_type}, Gothic illuminated border, no text`

**Ass (Ace):** `{STYLE_C_GLOBAL}, a single monumental {dark_fantasy_suit_symbol} of extraordinary power and detail, ancient and magical, radiating dark energy, centered on a stone altar in {suit_environment}, surrounded by Gothic architectural details and arcane symbols, {suit_colors} with dramatic light emanating from the symbol, maximum ornamentation, medieval manuscript illumination border, showcase piece, no text`

### Negative prompt for Style C
```
cartoon, anime, cute, chibi, bright cheerful colors, pastel, flat colors, clean 
minimalist lines, modern, sci-fi, neon, robotic, pixelated, low quality, blurry, 
extra fingers, bad anatomy, watermark, text, signature, oversaturated, washed-out, 
smooth plastic texture, stock photo, generic, happy, cheerful expressions
```

### Consistency enforcement for Style C

- **"DVD screengrab" prefix technique**: Adding `"DVD screengrab from dark fantasy film"` to every prompt locks in a consistent cinematic aesthetic with appropriate film grain and period lighting.
- **Fixed artist anchors**: Use the same 2-3 artist references (Greg Rutkowski, Craig Mullins, concept art) across every card.
- **Per-suit lighting protocol**: Bells always use torchlight. Shields always use cold moonlight. Acorns use ethereal forest light. Roses use candlelight. This creates visual sub-consistency within the broader dark style.
- **LoRA recommendation**: The **Fantasy Card Diffusion** model on HuggingFace (trained on ~35,000 MTG card artworks) provides an excellent starting point for dark fantasy card illustration.

---

## Production pipeline: from testing to automation

### Phase 1 — Manual testing on OpenArt.ai

Start with OpenArt's Essential plan ($7/month). Use **FLUX Dev** for maximum control (CFG slider, steps, seed). Upload a style reference image using Image Guidance. Test each template set by generating one card of each type (König, Ober, Under, pip, ace) across all four suits. Use the **Prompt Optimizer** toggle to compare raw vs. enhanced prompts. Save winning seeds. Use **FLUX Kontext Pro** for character consistency testing — upload a user photo and test face preservation on court cards. OpenArt's dedicated **Playing Card Generator** page provides additional tested prompts as baselines.

### Phase 2 — Workflow development in ComfyUI or Weavy.ai

Build the composite pipeline following the ArtisMysterium architecture: generate card elements (illustration, background, border) in separate lanes, then composite. Essential node packages: **WAS Node Suite** (Image Paste Crop, Create Grid Image), **ComfyUI Inspire Pack** (LoadPromptsFromFile for batch), **ComfyUI_IPAdapter_plus** (style transfer), **ComfyUI-PuLID-Flux** (face identity), **ComfyUI-TextOverlay** (card values and symbols).

For **face preservation on court cards**, the recommended modern approach chains FLUX Kontext (style/context) with PuLID (identity). The user uploads a single face photo; PuLID embeds identity features; Kontext ensures the stylized portrait matches the card deck's aesthetic. Weight/timeline controls adjust how strongly identity influences the final image.

Alternatively, build the same pipeline visually in **Weavy.ai** using its Text Iterator + Array Nodes for batch processing. Weavy's advantage is parallel cloud generation (36 servers simultaneously) and built-in compositing. Its limitation is less granular parameter control than ComfyUI. The free tier (150 credits) can prototype one full deck with Flux Fast.

### Phase 3 — Batch automation

Define all 36 cards in a **CSV file** with columns: `suit, rank, card_type, content_prompt, is_face_card, face_reference_path`. Write a Python script that loads the base ComfyUI workflow JSON, iterates through all 36 rows, modifies the prompt node and input image references, and queues each via the ComfyUI REST API (`POST /prompt`). Monitor completion via WebSocket. Estimated generation time: **2-5 minutes per card** with FLUX, ~30 seconds with SDXL.

For quality control, adopt the NEAR Monsters approach: build an accept/reject webapp where each generated card is reviewed before advancing. Generate **4-9 variants per card** and select the best. Budget 30-50% of total production time for post-processing refinement.

### Phase 4 — Print preparation

Upscale all cards to **300 DPI print resolution** using Real-ESRGAN 4× or Topaz upscaling nodes. Apply batch color correction to ensure palette consistency across all 36 cards. Overlay final card borders, suit symbols, and rank indicators in Python (PIL/Pillow) or Figma for precise alignment. Services like **MakePlayingCards.com** (no minimum order, used by Kickstarter creators) or PrinterStudio handle physical production.

---

## Critical findings and what to watch for

**AI-generated tessellations (Style B) are the hardest to execute** — models consistently fail at mathematically perfect interlocking patterns. Plan for heavy ControlNet guidance using pre-designed geometric templates, or embrace "Escher-inspired" rather than "mathematically precise Escher" as the creative direction.

**Artist name references** (Greg Rutkowski, Miyazaki) work powerfully for style direction but raise ethical and legal questions for commercial products. Consider using **style descriptions** rather than living artist names in final production prompts. "Oil painting concept art with dramatic chiaroscuro and rich atmospheric depth" achieves similar results to naming specific artists.

**FLUX.2 does not support negative prompts** — all style enforcement must be done through positive description. FLUX.1 Dev still supports negatives via CFG guidance. For Swiss Jass production, FLUX.1 Dev with LoRA or FLUX Kontext with reference images is the recommended model path.

The **commercial market for AI card decks is proven**. AI-generated tarot decks sell for $5-$80 on Etsy (hundreds of active listings). Multiple Kickstarter campaigns have shipped AI-generated card products. Transparency about AI involvement is increasingly expected by buyers.

## Conclusion

The three prompt template sets provide a complete, production-ready foundation for generating Swiss Jass decks across radically different aesthetics. The cartoon style is the most forgiving for AI generation — bright colors and exaggerated features mask inconsistencies. The dark fantasy style produces the most visually impressive results thanks to FLUX and SDXL's natural strength with dramatic lighting and detailed textures. The Escher geometric style demands the most human intervention but yields the most distinctive product.

The most effective production architecture combines **OpenArt.ai for rapid prototyping** (test 10-20 cards manually, identify optimal prompts and seeds), **ComfyUI for automated batch generation** (36 cards via API with Inspire Pack or Python scripting), and **Weavy.ai as an optional visual pipeline builder** when iterating on the composite workflow. Each platform serves a distinct phase of the production cycle, and the modular prompt template system ensures prompts transfer cleanly between all three.

artifacts.refined_concept:
# Personalized Swiss Jass Card Platform - Concept Summary

## 1. Problem Statement

Generic personalized playing card services lack **emotional depth** and **cultural authenticity**. Swiss Jass players specifically have limited options for custom decks that honor traditional iconography (Schellen, Schilten, Eicheln, Rosen suits) while enabling personal connections. Existing custom card printers (MakePlayingCards.com, PrintNinja) offer generic templates but no AI-assisted design tools or cultural specialization.

## 2. Target Users

**Primary segments (all targeted via A/B testing):**

- **Gift-givers**: People seeking unique personalized presents for occasions (birthdays, weddings, bachelor parties, family reunions) — care about emotional impact and fast turnaround
- **Game enthusiasts**: Players wanting quality custom decks for regular game nights — care about durability, print quality, and replayability
- **Swiss expats/heritage communities**: Diaspora seeking culturally authentic Jass decks with personal twist — care about traditional symbolism and nostalgia

## 3. Proposed Solution

An **e-commerce platform** where users create custom Swiss Jass decks by:
1. Uploading photos of friends/family (12+ faces for court cards)
2. Selecting art style (Fun Cartoon, Escher Geometric, Dark Fantasy, or custom)
3. AI transforms uploaded faces into styled card characters while preserving identity
4. Customizing both front and back of cards with AI-assisted generation
5. Receiving professionally printed decks (300 DPI, premium materials)

**Core mechanism**: **FLUX Kontext + PuLID face preservation** pipeline ensures uploaded faces maintain identity while matching the chosen artistic style. Users get a deck featuring their people as the König, Ober, and Under characters across all four suits.

## 4. Key Features

**V1 (full-featured launch):**

- **Photo-to-character AI pipeline**: Upload faces → AI generates styled court card portraits
- **Three complete art style templates**: 
  - Fun Cartoon (ligne claire, Ghibli-inspired)
  - Escher Geometric (impossible tessellations, Art Deco)
  - Dark Fantasy (Game of Thrones aesthetic, medieval manuscript borders)
- **Modular prompt architecture**: Separates style/composition/content/quality layers for consistency across all 36 cards
- **Cultural authenticity**: Proper Swiss Jass suits (Schellen/Bells, Schilten/Shields, Eicheln/Acorns, Rosen/Roses) with traditional iconography
- **Custom front & back design**: Users customize both card faces and deck backs
- **Premium print preparation**: 300 DPI upscaling, color correction, professional fulfillment
- **Design wizard**: Guided UI for non-designers (simple path) + advanced controls for enthusiasts

**Technical pipeline:**
- **Testing/prototyping**: OpenArt.ai (FLUX Dev, rapid iteration)
- **Batch generation**: ComfyUI with FLUX Kontext + PuLID (face identity preservation)
- **Workflow orchestration**: Weavy.ai (visual pipeline builder, parallel cloud generation)
- **Automation**: Python scripts via ComfyUI REST API for 36-card batch processing

## 5. Differentiation

**What makes this unique:**

- **Emotional + cultural fusion**: Only platform combining personal face customization with authentic Swiss Jass cultural elements
- **AI-native architecture**: Built ground-up with Claude Code, Opus 4.6 multi-agent harness, and modern diffusion models — enables scale impossible for traditional design services
- **Style diversity**: Three radically different aesthetic templates (cartoon, geometric, dark fantasy) vs. generic photo filters
- **Face preservation quality**: FLUX Kontext + PuLID achieves "zero model pollution" — your face in any art style without losing identity or corrupting the deck's aesthetic
- **Swiss Jass specialization**: Proper 36-card format, traditional suits, cultural authenticity for diaspora market (vs. generic 52-card poker decks)

**vs. MakePlayingCards.com**: They offer blank templates; we offer AI-powered design automation  
**vs. Etsy AI card sellers**: They sell pre-made decks; we offer full personalization  
**vs. Traditional designers**: They charge $500+ for custom illustration; we automate at scale

## 6. Success Criteria

**Phase 1 (MVP validation — 6 months):**
- 100 decks sold across all three target segments
- <15% design revision requests (AI generation quality threshold)
- 4.5+ star average rating (emotional resonance + quality)
- 30% repeat/referral rate (gift-givers recommending to others)

**Phase 2 (Market fit — 12 months):**
- Expand beyond Jass to poker, tarot, other card game formats
- $100k revenue (sustainable unit economics)
- Clear identification of highest-value segment (focus strategy)

**Technical milestones:**
- <5 min generation time per complete 36-card deck
- 90%+ face identity preservation rate (PuLID success threshold)
- Batch automation operational (no manual intervention per order)

## 7. Scope & Constraints

**Timeline**: 6 months to MVP launch  
**Investment**: $50k

**In scope (V1):**
- Swiss Jass 36-card format only
- Three pre-defined art style templates (cartoon, geometric, dark fantasy)
- Photo upload → AI character generation for court cards (König, Ober, Under)
- Custom card backs with AI assistance
- Premium print fulfillment partnership
- Simple design wizard + advanced customization mode
- Web platform (desktop-first, mobile-responsive)

**Out of scope (V1):**
- Other card formats (poker, tarot, bridge) — **post-MVP expansion**
- Custom art style training (users bring their own style references) — **V2 feature**
- Physical retail distribution — **digital-only initially**
- International shipping beyond EU/US — **constrained initially**
- Real-time collaborative design (multiple users editing one deck) — **future consideration**

**Technical constraints:**
- FLUX.2 lacks negative prompt support → use FLUX.1 Dev with LoRA or Kontext with references
- Escher geometric style requires heavy ControlNet guidance or post-processing (hardest to automate)
- Face preservation quality depends on photo quality (users must upload clear, well-lit portraits)
- Batch generation time: 2-5 min/card with FLUX (30 sec with SDXL fallback)

**Key risks:**
- **AI consistency challenges**: Maintaining visual coherence across 36 cards (mitigated by modular prompt architecture + Kontext)
- **Print quality expectations**: Users expect physical product to match digital preview (mitigated by upscaling + test prints)
- **Cultural authenticity**: Swiss Jass community may reject AI-generated interpretations of traditional symbols (mitigated by community feedback loops)
- **Market saturation**: AI card decks proliferating on Etsy (differentiation via personalization + quality)
- **Artist attribution ethics**: Using style references without compensation (mitigated by avoiding living artist names in production prompts)

---

**This concept is ready for council evaluation.** Key decision points: technical feasibility of 6-month timeline with AI-native tooling, market validation approach for three overlapping segments, and risk mitigation for AI generation quality at scale.

selected_council.focus: Evaluates the technical viability of maintaining face identity and visual coherence across 36 cards using FLUX Kontext + PuLID, within the 5-minute generation constraint. Assesses batch automation risks, style template complexity (especially Escher geometric), and quality degradation at scale.
evaluation_criteria: Face preservation success rate across art styles (PuLID identity retention)
Visual consistency across 36-card deck (style coherence, color palette stability)
Generation speed feasibility (5 min/deck target vs. 2-5 min/card reality)
Automation reliability (REST API orchestration, error recovery)
Escher geometric style technical achievability (ControlNet/post-processing complexity)

selected_council.focus: Assesses whether AI-generated interpretations of traditional Swiss Jass iconography (Schellen, Schilten, Eicheln, Rosen) will resonate with or alienate the target diaspora community. Evaluates cultural sensitivity risks and authentic representation vs. AI reinterpretation tension.
evaluation_criteria: Traditional iconography accuracy (suit symbols, court card hierarchy)
Diaspora market receptivity to AI-styled cultural elements
Risk of cultural appropriation or misrepresentation
Swiss expat community size & purchasing power validation
Competitive authenticity vs. existing Swiss card manufacturers

selected_council.focus: Evaluates the critical gap between AI-generated digital previews and physical printed decks. Assesses 300 DPI upscaling quality, color calibration challenges, material selection impact on artwork perception, and managing customer disappointment when physical ≠ screen.
evaluation_criteria: Upscaling quality from AI output to 300 DPI print-ready files
Color accuracy between screen preview and printed cards (RGB to CMYK)
Material/finish impact on art style presentation (linen vs. smooth, matte vs. gloss)
Test print validation process before customer fulfillment
Customer satisfaction risk from preview-to-product mismatch

selected_council.focus: Evaluates pricing strategy for emotionally-driven gift purchases across three segments (weddings, bachelor parties, family reunions). Assesses willingness-to-pay for AI-personalized vs. traditional custom design, referral mechanics for viral gift-giving, and lifetime value of gift-givers vs. enthusiasts.
evaluation_criteria: Price elasticity for personalized gifts (AI custom vs. $500 designer alternative)
Occasion-based marketing effectiveness (wedding/birthday urgency premium)
Referral/word-of-mouth potential (viral coefficient for gift recipients becoming buyers)
Repeat purchase likelihood by segment (one-time gifters vs. enthusiast collectors)
Revenue concentration risk (dependency on gift segment vs. diversified demand)

selected_council.agent_name: AI Ethics & Content Rights Compliance Agent
selected_council.focus: Assesses legal and ethical risks from using face uploads (consent, privacy, misuse), style training on artist references (IP infringement, living artist attribution ethics), and cultural symbol commercialization. Evaluates mitigation strategies for artist community backlash and GDPR/data protection compliance.
evaluation_criteria: Face upload consent & privacy compliance (GDPR, data retention policies)
Artist style attribution ethics (avoiding living artist names, training data transparency)
Cultural appropriation risk (commercializing Swiss heritage symbols)
Deepfake/misuse potential (face generation without subject consent)
Terms of Service robustness (limiting liability for controversial card content)

evaluation.reasoning:
The technical architecture is well-researched and uses appropriate tools (FLUX Kontext + PuLID, ComfyUI compositing, modular prompts), but contains a critical feasibility gap and several reliability concerns:

**Fatal Speed Contradiction:** The concept claims a '5-minute generation constraint' but states '2-5 minutes per card' in the pipeline section. Basic math: 36 cards × 2-5 min = 72-180 minutes (14-36× slower than target). Even with Weavy's parallel cloud processing, 36 simultaneous FLUX generations would be prohibitively expensive and the document provides no cost analysis for this approach.

**Face Preservation Realism:** While PuLID + FLUX Kontext is the current best-in-class approach, the concept glosses over identity retention challenges across three radically different art styles. Cartoon style (exaggerated features, ligne claire) and geometric Escher style will struggle significantly more than the dark fantasy photorealistic style. The acknowledgment of '4-9 variants per card' and '30-50% time for post-processing' suggests the authors expect significant failure rates but don't quantify them.

**Consistency Gaps:** The modular prompt system is sound, but the concept lacks critical technical details: no seed management strategy across 36 cards, no quantitative consistency metrics, and color palette stability relegated to post-processing batch correction rather than generation-time enforcement. The document admits 'even with fixed style layers, diffusion models introduce variance' but provides no mitigation beyond LoRA and reference images.

**Escher Style Acknowledged as Non-Viable:** The concept is admirably honest that 'AI struggles with true mathematical tessellations,' 'models consistently fail at mathematically perfect interlocking patterns,' and recommends 'significant post-processing' or accepting 'Escher-inspired' rather than precise tessellations. This effectively admits 1/3 of the proposed styles cannot be achieved as described through AI generation alone.

**Automation Reliability Unaddressed:** The ComfyUI REST API pipeline lacks error handling, retry logic, or automated quality gating. The NEAR Monsters reference (manual review webapp) and '4-9 variants per card' recommendation reveal that fully automated generation isn't reliable enough for unattended production. No discussion of failed generation detection or recovery.

**What Works:** The composite architecture (separate lanes for illustration/background/border) is proven effective by community workflows. The modular prompt template system with four layers (style/composition/content/quality) is well-designed for batch generation. The platform comparison (OpenArt → ComfyUI → production) is logical. Using existing LoRAs (Fantasy Card Diffusion, ligne claire) is pragmatic.
concerns: 5-minute deck generation claim contradicts 2-5 min/card reality by 14-36× — mathematically impossible without addressing cost of massive parallelization
Face identity preservation success rate across cartoon and geometric styles likely <50% without extensive regeneration — PuLID optimized for photorealistic outputs
No seed management or deterministic generation strategy documented — consistency will degrade across 36-card batch
Escher geometric style explicitly acknowledged as requiring heavy manual intervention or abandoning mathematical precision — 1/3 of concept non-viable as described
Automation pipeline lacks error handling, quality gating, or retry logic — '4-9 variants per card' implies high failure rate with manual review required
Color palette consistency deferred to post-processing rather than enforced at generation time — batch color correction can introduce artifacts
No VRAM/hardware requirements specified for FLUX Kontext + PuLID — document mentions 12GB minimum but 36-card batch memory management unaddressed
Commercial viability assumption based on tarot deck market may not transfer to Swiss Jass niche — no market validation for AI-generated regional card games

evaluation.reasoning: This concept demonstrates strong technical competence in AI card generation but reveals a fundamental disconnect from Swiss cultural authenticity and diaspora market realities. Swiss Jass is not merely a card game—it is Switzerland's national card game with 500+ years of standardized iconography deeply embedded in regional identity. The four suits (Schellen, Schilten, Eicheln, Rosen) have canonical visual representations that Swiss players across generations instantly recognize. The proposal offers three radical aesthetic departures—'whimsical cartoon,' 'Escher geometric,' and 'Game of Thrones dark fantasy'—none of which show engagement with actual traditional Swiss Jass card design (exemplified by AG Müller's 200-year manufacturing tradition). The Swiss diaspora market is small (~800,000 worldwide) but affluent and culturally protective. They purchase Jass cards as cultural touchstones and nostalgia objects, not as experimental art pieces. The document contains zero references to: consulting Swiss cultural advisors, studying traditional Jass card aesthetics, understanding regional variations (Deutschschweiz vs. Romandie preferences), or assessing how AI reinterpretation might be received. The technical pipeline is production-ready, but it's optimized for generating novel fantasy card decks—not for serving a diaspora community seeking authentic cultural connection. Most critically, the concept treats Swiss iconography as aesthetic raw material for AI experimentation rather than as cultural heritage requiring respectful interpretation.
concerns: No traditional Swiss Jass aesthetic among three proposed styles—cartoon/Escher/dark fantasy bear no resemblance to canonical AG Müller or traditional Swiss card designs
Zero evidence of cultural consultation, Swiss design research, or understanding of Jass iconographic standards (court card hierarchy, suit symbol conventions)
Swiss diaspora market is small (~800K globally) and primarily seeks authentic cultural products for nostalgia/heritage connection, not experimental AI art
AI reinterpretation of centuries-old cultural symbols without acknowledgment of sensitivity risks—no discussion of how Swiss community might perceive this
Competitive positioning unclear: AG Müller dominates with traditional designs; modern Swiss designers (Jass Plus, limited editions) maintain cultural grounding while innovating
Document focuses entirely on technical AI generation capabilities while treating Swiss cultural elements as interchangeable fantasy themes
Risk of cultural appropriation narrative: using Swiss heritage symbols as aesthetic material for AI art products marketed to non-Swiss audiences
No market validation: no evidence of Swiss diaspora interest in AI-generated cultural products, no surveys of Jass player preferences, no prototype testing with target community

evaluation.reasoning: This concept demonstrates strong digital workflow mastery but critical blindness to print production realities. The RGB-to-CMYK color shift problem is completely unaddressed—the 'golden yellow,' 'warm amber,' 'deep crimson,' and 'blood-red' colors specified will shift significantly muddy/dull in CMYK printing, especially problematic for the Schellen (bells) and Rosen (roses) suits. The upscaling strategy mentions Real-ESRGAN 4× but provides no target print dimensions or validation methodology; upscaling artifacts will be most visible in Style B (Escher geometric) with its 'intricate linework' and 'lithographic precision.' No material/finish selection guidance exists—the 'linen finish' offered by MakePlayingCards.com will destroy the fine detail in geometric tessellations that the prompts emphasize. Most critically, the entire quality control workflow is screen-based digital validation with NO physical test print stage before customer fulfillment. The '4-9 variants per card' selection happens on RGB monitors, creating a preview-to-product expectation gap. The document acknowledges Style B requires 'significant post-processing' due to AI tessellation failures but doesn't budget for print testing iterations. The only physical production mention is a single sentence naming MakePlayingCards.com—no discussion of their material options, color calibration services, or proof-before-production offerings.
concerns: No RGB-to-CMYK conversion testing or soft-proofing workflow—reds, oranges, and golds will shift significantly duller in print
Zero physical test print validation before full production run—all QA happens on screens viewing RGB
No material/finish selection strategy—linen texture will obscure Escher geometric fine details, smooth stock needed
Upscaling methodology (Real-ESRGAN 4×) mentioned but no artifact testing or target print dimension specifications
Style B (Escher) acknowledged as 'hardest to execute' with AI tessellation failures, yet no print complexity mitigation
Dark Fantasy style's 'dramatic chiaroscuro' and 'deep shadows' will compress/flatten in CMYK gamut limitations
Customer expectation management completely absent—no strategy for managing digital preview vs physical product gap
No mention of MakePlayingCards.com color profiles, calibration services, or proof samples—treating print as afterthought

evaluation.reasoning: This concept has severe structural problems as a gift-oriented business despite strong technical execution. The fatal flaw: it's positioned as an AI art generation pipeline for Swiss Jass cards, NOT as an emotionally-driven gift product. Key findings: (1) The $5-$80 Etsy AI card range cited shows massive market confusion about AI-generated card value - no clear willingness-to-pay signal emerges. (2) Swiss Jass's cultural specificity limits the addressable gift market to ~8-10M people (Switzerland + southern Germany) vs. 100M+ for standard playing cards. (3) The three aesthetic styles (cartoon, Escher, dark fantasy) are creator-driven art experiments, not occasion-targeted gift products - there's ZERO mention of weddings, birthdays, or family reunion positioning despite the Council brief specifically calling for this. (4) True personalization (faces of wedding couple/family on court cards via PuLID) is buried in technical documentation rather than positioned as the core emotional value prop. (5) Playing cards inherently have strong social/viral potential (used in groups, visible to others), but this is completely unexploited - no referral mechanics, no 'gift the deck, recipients become buyers' funnel. (6) Repeat purchase dynamics are terrible: how many Jass decks does one person need? The enthusiast collector segment for Swiss Jass is minuscule compared to poker/tarot collectors. (7) Revenue concentration risk is extreme - entire business depends on a hyperspecific regional card game format with no clear adjacent markets. The document spends 90% discussing ComfyUI workflows and prompt engineering, 0% discussing gift-giving psychology, occasion-based urgency premiums, or emotional attachment strategies. This is a technical art project masquerading as a gift business.
concerns: No occasion-based positioning despite Council brief mentioning weddings/bachelor parties/family reunions - critical gift psychology hook is completely missing
Swiss Jass market is 50-100x smaller than standard playing cards - hyperspecific regional format creates insurmountable TAM ceiling
Cited $5-$80 Etsy AI card pricing shows severe market confusion - no clear willingness-to-pay for AI-generated cards vs. $500 traditional custom design alternative

Personalization capability (face-swapping via PuLID) is buried in technical docs rather than positioned as core emotional value - missing the 'your faces on royal court cards' wedding gift angle entirely
Zero repeat purchase mechanism - one-time gift purchase model with no consumables, expansions, or seasonal editions to drive LTV
No referral/viral mechanics despite cards being inherently social products used in groups - missing word-of-mouth multiplication entirely
Revenue heavily concentrated in tiny enthusiast collector segment (Swiss Jass collectors) rather than diversified across gift occasions
Production complexity (2-5 min/card, 30-50% post-processing time) incompatible with last-minute gift urgency premiums that drive gift pricing power

agents.agent_name: AI Ethics & Content Rights Compliance Agent

evaluation.agent_name: AI Ethics & Content Rights Compliance Agent
evaluation.reasoning: This concept presents severe legal and ethical risks across multiple dimensions. **Face upload consent (GDPR/biometric data)**: The proposal to use PuLID and FLUX Kontext for 'face preservation on court cards' with user-uploaded photos creates immediate GDPR Article 9 'special category data' concerns. Biometric data processed for identification requires explicit consent, transparent data retention policies, and right-to-erasure mechanisms. The document provides no framework for: consent documentation, data minimization (why store faces beyond generation?), cross-border transfer compliance (cloud servers 'spinning up in parallel' suggests multi-jurisdiction processing), or breach notification procedures. If faces are stored for batch generation or quality control, retention periods must be defined and justified. **Artist attribution ethics**: The explicit recommendation to use living artist names (Greg Rutkowski, Craig Mullins, Miyazaki) 'for style direction' then switch to 'style descriptions' for 'final production prompts' demonstrates awareness of ethical problems while proposing to exploit them anyway during development. Greg Rutkowski has publicly objected to his name being used in AI prompts without consent; the document acknowledges this raises 'ethical and legal questions' but treats it as optional to address. Training data transparency is absent—FLUX, SDXL, and other models cited have undisclosed training sets that almost certainly include copyrighted artwork without artist consent. **Cultural appropriation risk**: Swiss Jass cards are a living cultural tradition with 500+ years of history. Commercializing AI-generated versions as a 'proven market' (comparing to Etsy tarot decks) treats cultural heritage as extractable IP. No consultation with Swiss card-making guilds, cultural heritage organizations, or traditional manufacturers is proposed. The framing as 'Swiss Jass AI card deck generator' positions this as a scalable product rather than respectful artistic homage. **Deepfake/misuse potential**: The PuLID face-swapping capability ('zero model pollution—preserving artistic style while swapping faces') is explicitly a deepfake technology. The document proposes 'user uploads a single face photo' with no verification that the uploader owns rights to that face. This enables: inserting non-consenting individuals into fantasy/dark imagery, creating commercial products featuring someone's likeness without permission, and generating court cards with celebrity faces for resale. The 'Dark Fantasy' style with 'battle-scarred,' 'haunting,' 'bleeding' imagery compounds harm potential. **Terms of Service gaps**: The document mentions 'transparency about AI involvement is increasingly expected' but provides no ToS framework addressing: who owns generated cards (user? platform? co-ownership?), liability for copyright infringement from training data, liability for rights-of-publicity violations from face uploads, restrictions on generating offensive/illegal content, or dispute resolution for controversial card imagery. The proposal to sell on platforms like Etsy suggests consumer-facing commerce, which amplifies liability exposure. **Mitigating factors**: The document does acknowledge some risks ('ethical and legal questions,' artist name concerns) and commercial AI card decks do exist in market. However, awareness without mitigation is insufficient—especially for a tool designed for 'production pipeline' at scale.
concerns: No GDPR-compliant consent/retention framework for biometric face data uploaded by users
Explicit recommendation to use living artist names (Greg Rutkowski, others) without consent during development phase
Training data transparency completely absent—models built on undisclosed copyrighted artwork
Deepfake-enabling face-swap technology (PuLID) with no verification that uploader has rights to the face
Cultural heritage commercialization: Swiss Jass cards treated as extractable IP with no stakeholder consultation
No Terms of Service framework for liability (copyright infringement, rights-of-publicity, offensive content)
Face generation for 'Dark Fantasy' violent/disturbing imagery without subject consent safeguards
'DVD screengrab' and artist name prompts may infringe film/artist trademarks
Cross-border data processing implied ('cloud servers spinning up in parallel') without transfer safeguards
Etsy/commercial marketplace strategy exposes consumers to IP-tainted products with unclear ownership
Batch automation of 36 cards amplifies scale of potential rights violations per deck
No age verification or content restrictions for face uploads (child safety risk)

Biometric data processed for identification requires explicit consent, transparent data retention policies, and right-to-erasure mechanisms. The document provides no framework for: consent documentation, data minimization (why store faces beyond generation?), cross-border transfer compliance (cloud servers 'spinning up in parallel' suggests multi-jurisdiction processing), or breach notification procedures. If faces are stored for batch generation or quality control, retention periods must be defined and justified. **Artist attribution ethics**: The explicit recommendation to use living artist names (Greg Rutkowski, Craig Mullins, Miyazaki) 'for style direction' then switch to 'style descriptions' for 'final production prompts' demonstrates awareness of ethical problems while proposing to exploit them anyway during development. Greg Rutkowski has publicly objected to his name being used in AI prompts without consent; the document acknowledges this raises 'ethical and legal questions' but treats it as optional to address. Training data transparency is absent—FLUX, SDXL, and other models cited have undisclosed training sets that almost certainly include copyrighted artwork without artist consent. **Cultural appropriation risk**: Swiss Jass cards are a living cultural tradition with 500+ years of history. Commercializing AI-generated versions as a 'proven market' (comparing to Etsy tarot decks) treats cultural heritage as extractable IP. No consultation with Swiss card-making guilds, cultural heritage organizations, or traditional manufacturers is proposed. The framing as 'Swiss Jass AI card deck generator' positions this as a scalable product rather than respectful artistic homage. **Deepfake/misuse potential**: The PuLID face-swapping capability ('zero model pollution—preserving artistic style while swapping faces') is explicitly a deepfake technology. The document proposes 'user uploads a single face photo' with no verification that the uploader owns rights to that face. This enables: inserting non-consenting individuals into fantasy/dark imagery, creating commercial products featuring someone's likeness without permission, and generating court cards with celebrity faces for resale. The 'Dark Fantasy' style with 'battle-scarred,' 'haunting,' 'bleeding' imagery compounds harm potential. **Terms of Service gaps**: The document mentions 'transparency about AI involvement is increasingly expected' but provides no ToS framework addressing: who owns generated cards (user? platform? co-ownership?), liability for copyright infringement from training data, liability for rights-of-publicity violations from face uploads, restrictions on generating offensive/illegal content, or dispute resolution for controversial card imagery. The proposal to sell on platforms like Etsy suggests consumer-facing commerce, which amplifies liability exposure. **Mitigating factors**: The document does acknowledge some risks ('ethical and legal questions,' artist name concerns) and commercial AI card decks do exist in market. However, awareness without mitigation is insufficient—especially for a tool designed for 'production pipeline' at scale.
concerns: No GDPR-compliant consent/retention framework for biometric face data uploaded by users
Explicit recommendation to use living artist names (Greg Rutkowski, others) without consent during development phase
Training data transparency completely absent—models built on undisclosed copyrighted artwork
Deepfake-enabling face-swap technology (PuLID) with no verification that uploader has rights to the face
Cultural heritage commercialization: Swiss Jass cards treated as extractable IP with no stakeholder consultation
No Terms of Service framework for liability (copyright infringement, rights-of-publicity, offensive content)
Face generation for 'Dark Fantasy' violent/disturbing imagery without subject consent safeguards
'DVD screengrab' and artist name prompts may infringe film/artist trademarks
Cross-border data processing implied ('cloud servers spinning up in parallel') without transfer safeguards
Etsy/commercial marketplace strategy exposes consumers to IP-tainted products with unclear ownership
Batch automation of 36 cards amplifies scale of potential rights violations per deck
No age verification or content restrictions for face uploads (child safety risk)

council_verdict.synthesized_reasoning: This concept demonstrates exceptional AI generation technical depth but suffers from fatal misalignment between capability and market need. The core contradiction: it's a sophisticated art generation pipeline masquerading as a culturally-grounded gift business. Five critical failure modes converge: (1) Mathematical impossibility—the claimed 5-minute deck generation contradicts documented 2-5 min/card reality by 14-36×, making the speed premise false; (2) Cultural authenticity void—zero engagement with traditional Swiss Jass aesthetics or stakeholders, treating 500-year-old heritage symbols as interchangeable fantasy themes (cartoon/Escher/Game of Thrones) with no resemblance to canonical designs Swiss diaspora would recognize; (3) Legal/ethical time bombs—GDPR biometric consent gaps, artist name exploitation, deepfake misuse potential, all acknowledged but unmitigated; (4) Print production blindness—RGB-only QA workflow ignores CMYK color shifts that will destroy specified palettes, no physical test prints before customer fulfillment; (5) Gift economics inversion—personalization (face-swapping) buried as technical feature rather than positioned as core emotional value, zero occasion-based marketing despite Council brief mentioning weddings/reunions. The author has built an impressive ComfyUI/FLUX technical showcase optimized for AI art experimentation, not for serving the actual tiny (~800K) Swiss diaspora market seeking authentic cultural connection. The $5-80 Etsy AI card pricing cited shows market confusion, not validated demand. One-time purchase dynamics, 50-100× smaller TAM than standard cards, and hyperspecific regional format create insurmountable business constraints. Most damning: 90% of documentation discusses prompt engineering and node workflows, 0% discusses gift-giving psychology or cultural sensitivity—revealing the author's true focus.
next_steps: **Reject this concept** due to fundamental product-market mismatch and unresolved legal/ethical risks

Provide feedback to author: technical AI generation skills are strong, but Swiss Jass required cultural authenticity research (AG Müller traditional designs, Swiss diaspora consultation) that is completely absent
If reconsidering this space, start from opposite direction: interview 50+ Swiss diaspora members about what Jass cards mean to them culturally, THEN determine if AI generation serves that need
Flag the 5-minute generation claim as mathematically impossible (36 cards × 2-5 min = 72-180 min) and require honest timeline disclosure in any future AI card concepts

Establish clearer Council evaluation criteria: technical sophistication alone is insufficient; cultural sensitivity, legal compliance, and gift psychology fundamentals are mandatory for personalized gift products

For AI-generated cultural products generally, require: (a) stakeholder consultation documentation, (b) GDPR-compliant consent workflows for biometric data, (c) physical print validation before production, (d) clear artist attribution ethics, (e) occasion-based gift positioning from day one
council_composition: AI Ethics & Content Rights Compliance Agent
